0.title: Care About Your Craft
0.body: Why spend your life developing software unless you care about doing it well?

1.title: Think! About Your Work
1.body: Turn off the autopilot and take control. Constantly critique and appraise your work.

2.title: Provide Options, Don't Make Lame Excuses
2.body: Instead of excuses, provide options. Don't say it can't be done; explain what can be done.

3.title: Don't Live with Broken Windows
3.body: Fix bad designs, wrong decisions, and poor code when you see them.

4.title: Be a Catalyst for Change
4.body: You can't force change on people. Instead, show them how the future might be and help them participate in creating it.

5.title: Remember the Big Picture
5.body: Don't get so engrossed in the details that you forget to check what's happening around you.

6.title: Make Quality a Requirements Issue
6.body: Involve your users in determining the project's real quality requirements.

7.title: Invest Regularly in Your Knowledge Portfolio

8.title: Critically Analyze What You Read and Hear
8.body: Don't be swayed by vendors, media hype, or dogma. Analyze information in terms of you and your project.

9.title: It's Both What You Say and the Way You Say It
9.body: There's no point in having great ideas if you don't communicate them effectively.

10.title: DRY–Don't Repeat Yourself
10.body: Every piece of knowledge must have a single, unambiguous, authoritative representation within a system.

11.title: Make It Easy to Reuse
11.body: If it's easy to reuse, people will. Create an environment that supports reuse.

12.title: Eliminate Effects Between Unrelated Things
12.body: Design components that are self-contained. independent, and have a single, well-defined purpose.

13.title: There Are No Final Decisions
13.body: No decision is cast in stone. Instead, consider each as being written in the sand at the beach, and plan for change.

14.title: Use Tracer Bullets to Find the Target
14.body: Tracer bullets let you home in on your target by trying things and seeing how close they land.

15.title: Prototype to Learn
15.body: Prototyping is a learning experience. Its value lies not in the code you produce, but in the lessons you learn.

16.title: Program Close to the Problem Domain
16.body: Design and code in your user's language.

17.title: Estimate to Avoid Surprises
17.body: Estimate before you start. You'll spot potential problems up front.

18.title: Iterate the Schedule with the Code
18.body: Use experience you gain as you implement to refine the project time scales.

19.title: Keep Knowledge in Plain Text
19.body: Plain text won't become obsolete. It helps leverage your work and simplifies debugging and testing.

20.title: Use the Power of Command Shells
20.body: Use the shell when graphical user interfaces don't cut it.

21.title: Use a Single Editor Well
21.body: The editor should be an extension of your hand; make sure your editor is configurable, extensible, and programmable.

22.title: Always Use Source Code Control
22.body: Source code control is a time machine for your work—you can go back.

23.title: Fix the Problem, Not the Blame
23.body: It doesn't really matter whether the bug is your fault or someoneelse's—it is still your problem, and it still needs to be fixed.

24.title: Don't Panic When Debugging
24.body: Take a deep breath and THINK! about what could be causing the bug.

25.title: "select" Isn't Broken.
25.body: It is rare to find a bug in the OS or the compiler, or even a third-party product or library. The bug ismost likely in the application.

26.title: Don't Assume It—Prove It
26.body: Prove your assumptions in the actual environment-- with real data and boundary conditions.

27.title: Learn a Text Manipulation Language.
27.body: You spend a large part of each day working with text. Why not have the computer do some of it for you?

28.title: Write Code That Writes Code
28.body: Code generators increase your productivity and help avoid duplication.

29.title: You Can't Write Perfect Software
29.body: Software can't be perfect. Protect your code and users from the inevitable errors.

30.title: Design with Contracts
30.body: Use contracts to document and verify that code does no more and no less than it claims to do.

31.title: Crash Early
31.body: A dead program normally does a lot less damage than a crippled one.

32.title: Use Assertions to Prevent the Impossible
32.body: Assertions validate your assumptions. Use them to protect your code from an uncertain world.

33.title: Use Exceptions for Exceptional ProblemsExceptions
33.body: can suffer from all the readability and maintainability problems ofclassic spaghetti code. Reserve exceptions for exceptional things.

34.title: Finish What You Start
34.body: Where possible, the routine or object that allocates a resource should be responsible for deallocating it.

35.title: Minimize Coupling Between Modules
35.body: Avoid coupling by writing "shy" code and applying the Law of Demeter.

36.title: Configure, Don't Integrate
36.body: Implement technology choices for an application as configuration options, not through integration or engineering.

37.title: Put Abstractions in Code, Details in Metadata
37.body: Program for the general case, and put the specifics outside the compiled code base.

38.title: Analyze Workflow to Improve Concurrency
38.body: Exploit concurrency in your user's workflow.

39.title: Design Using Services
39.body: Design in terms of services—independent, concurrent objects behind well-defined, consistent interfaces.

40.title: Always Design for Concurrency
40.body: Allow for concurrency, and you'll design cleaner interfaces with fewer assumptions.

41.title: Separate Views from Models
41.body: Gain flexibility at low cost by designing your application in terms of models and views.

42.title: Use Blackboards to Coordinate Workflow
42.body: Use blackboards to coordinate disparate facts and agents, while maintaining independence and isolation among participants.

43.title: Don't Program by Coincidence
43.body: Rely only on reliable things. Beware of accidental complexity, and don't confuse a happy coincidence with a purposeful plan.

44.title: Estimate the Order of Your Algorithms
44.body: Get a feel for how long things are likely to take before you write code.

45.title: Test Your Estimates
45.body: Mathematical analysis of algorithms doesn't tell you everything. Try timing your code in its target environment.

46.title: Refactor Early, Refactor OftenJust as you might
46.body: weed and rearrange a garden, rewrite, rework, and re-architect codewhen it needs it. Fix the root of the problem.

47.title: Design to Test
47.body: Start thinking about testing before you write a line of code.

48.title: Test Your Software, or Your Users Will
48.body: Test ruthlessly. Don't make your users find bugs for you.

49.title: Don't Use Wizard Code You Don't Understand
49.body: Wizards can generate reams of code. Make sure you understand all of it before you incorporate it into your project.

50.title: Don't Gather Requirements–Dig for Them
50.body: Requirements rarely lie on the surface. They're buried deep beneath layers of assumptions, misconceptions, and politics.

51.title: Workwith a User to Think Like a User
51.body: It's the best way to gain insight into how the system will really be used.

52.title: Abstractions Live Longer than DetailsInvest in the
52.body: abstraction, not the implementation. Abstractions can survive thebarrage of changes from different implementations and new technologies.

53.title: Use a Project Glossary
53.body: Create and maintain a single source of all the specific terms and vocabulary for a project.

54.title: Don't Think Outside the Box–Find the Box
54.body: When faced with an impossible problem, identify the real constraints. Ask yourself: "Does it have tobe done this way? Does it have to be done at all?"

55.title: Start When You're Ready.
55.body: You've been building experience all your life. Don't ignore niggling doubts.

56.title: Some Things Are Better Done than Described
56.body: Don't fall into the specification spiral—at some point you need to start coding.

57.title: Don't Be a Slave to Formal Methods.
57.body: Don't blindly adopt any technique without putting it into the context of your development practices and capabilities.

58.title: Costly Tools Don't Produce Better Designs
58.body: Beware of vendor hype, industry dogma, and the aura of the price tag. Judge tools on their merits.

59.title: Organize Teams Around Functionality
59.body: Don't separate designers from coders, testers from data modelers. Build teams the way you build code.

60.title: Don't Use Manual Procedures
60.body: A shell script or batch file will execute the same instructions, in the same order, time after time.

61.title: Test Early. Test Often. Test Automatically
61.body: Tests that run with every build are much more effective than test plans that sit on a shelf.

62.title: Coding Ain't Done 'Til All the Tests Run

63.title: Use Saboteurs to Test Your Testing
63.body: Introduce bugs on purpose in a separate copy of the source to verify that testing will catch them.

64.title: Test State Coverage, Not Code Coverage
64.body: Identify and test significant program states. Just testing lines of code isn't enough.

65.title: Find Bugs OnceOnce a human tester finds a bug, it
65.body: should be the last time a human tester finds that bug. Automatic testsshould check for it from then on.

66.title: English is Just a Programming Language
66.body: Write documents as you would write code: honor the DRY principle, use metadata, MVC, automatic generation, and so on.

67.title: Build Documentation In, Don't Bolt It On
67.body: Documentation created separately from code is less likely to be correct and up to date.

68.title: Gently Exceed Your Users' Expectations
68.body: Come to understand your users' expectations, then deliver just that little bit more.

69.title: Sign Your Work
69.body: Craftsmen of an earlier age were proud to sign their work. You should be, too.
